results.title: Animals of the rocky shore [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional, Scottish Marine Biological Station and J.V. Durden
results.brief_description: This film is a simple ecological study of animals whose structure and habits enable them to live on rocky shores both above and below the low-tide mark. The following animals are seen: the common starfish, brittle star, sea urchin, sea stickleback and gobies, the swimming crab, the whelk, the hermit crab (seen climbing into a shell), sea anenomes, polyp clava, and the sea-aquirt ciona. Between tide-marks on the exposed rock surface, mussels, limpets, winkles, and acorn barnacles are seen. The whole series of animals is related to problems of life on the rocky shore.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gaumont-British Instructional, Scottish Marine Biological Station and J.V. Durden

results.title: Animals of the rocky shore
results.creator_credit: W. Hugh Baddeley and Hugh Baddeley Productions
results.brief_description: This film presents creatures of the rocky shore. Close-ups of crabs are shown, revealing the complexity of the mouth parts. In deeper water mullet, pollack and bass are shown swimming. An egg-case is removed from a dogfish and the developing embryo is shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: W. Hugh Baddeley and Hugh Baddeley Productions

results.title: Animals of the Indian jungle
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and F Von Keller
results.brief_description: Explores the dense tropical rain forest of eastern India, showing close up views of representative animals in their native environment - the crocodile, tiger, python, cobra, mongoose, monkey and elephant. Describes and illustrates the pattern of survival in the jungle, pointing out the ways of the hunters and the defences of the hunted. Photography by Jack Cardiff. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Animals of the Arctic
results.creator_credit: Centron Films, Karl Maslowski and Stephen Maslowski
results.brief_description: This film introduces students to the wide variety of wildlife that roams the plains and seashores of the Arctic. It shows how the animals and birds have adapted to their environment. Photography: Karl and Stephen Maslowski. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Animals of Australia (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Australian animals are as varied as the continent itself- from the red kangaroos of the inland to the platypus of the eastern highlands. This documentary contains original footage by nature photographer David Corke, together with extracts from some of the best known Australian films such as “Birth of the Red Kangaroo”, “The Echidna”, “The Lyrebird and the Fairy Penguins”.

results.title: Animals of Australia
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: An overview of Australian animals, grouped according to their natural habitat - the dry inland, open forests, rain forests and coastal areas. Both well known and lesser known animals are seen. Elementary descriptive treatment. Suitable for primary school level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia

results.title: Animals of Asia
results.creator_credit: Chatsworth Film Productions and Centron Films
results.brief_description: An overview of animals and birds of Asia. Includes flying foxes, snakes, deer, tigers, mud skippers and orangutans. Written by Michael Boorer of the Zoological Society of London. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Animals in winter
results.creator_credit: Heinz Sielmann and Heinz Sielmann Productions
results.brief_description: The behaviour in winter of squirrels, hamsters, insects, frogs, butterflies and other creatures, showing how they cope with the rigours of cold and the shortage of food in order to survive until the spring. Intended for primary and secondary schools
